title: 111_s1457
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009" and involves reviews of special Federal Reserve credit facilities. The "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009" involves reviews of various credit facilities of the Federal Reserve System, including the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, and others. The "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009" allows the Comptroller General to review credit facilities such as the Revolving Credit Facility, reciprocal currency arrangements, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles used by the Federal Reserve System. The Comptroller General can conduct onsite examinations if deemed necessary. The "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009" authorizes the Comptroller General to review credit facilities established by the Board or any Federal Reserve bank. Access to records is granted to carry out this subsection. The "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009" authorizes the Comptroller General to review credit facilities established by the Board or any Federal Reserve bank. The Comptroller General shall have access to reports, workpapers, and correspondence related to the examinations of banks or bank holding companies, as well as access to officers, employees, contractors, and other agents of any credit facility upon request. Copies of books, accounts, and records can be made and retained by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General is authorized to review credit facilities established by the Board or any Federal Reserve bank. Access to records, copies, and property must be authorized, and unauthorized access is prohibited. The Comptroller General can provide a list of officers and employees who can access records for review or examination. The Comptroller General reviews credit facilities established by the Board or Federal Reserve banks. A report on each review must be submitted to Congress within 90 days, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for action. The Comptroller General has the authority to take appropriate administrative action. Section 714(f) of title 31, United States Code, added by this Act, will be repealed 5 years after enactment.
